summary: This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering the period from July 7 to August 10, 2019. It includes detailed medical encounter notes, vital signs, medication orders, health problem lists, and transfer documentation, providing a comprehensive view of his health status while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. A series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his medical intake, examinations, lab results, and prescribed medications during his incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July and August 2019. The documents detail his medical history, physical condition, and treatments for various issues including constipation, sleep apnea, and hypertriglyceridemia. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, detailing his health assessments, treatments, and a notable injury incident. It includes records of a neck injury on July 23, his refusal of an eye exam, and various medical evaluations leading up to his death. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons medical records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering the period from July to August 2019. It includes routine health screenings, treatment refusal forms, and a detailed clinical encounter report from August 10, 2019, documenting a cardiac arrest and resuscitation attempt in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Health Services Clinical Encounter record for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, dated July 30, 2019. It details a medical evaluation where Epstein reported being without his medications for about a week, numbness in his right arm, and an inability to sleep due to lack of access to his CPAP machine. The record includes his vital signs, medical assessments, and new medication and test orders.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the medical encounter. He is evaluated for various complaints including being without his medications, right arm numbness, and sleep issues due to lack of his CPAP machine.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of all medical records, detailing his health complaints, treatments, and an injury incident in his cell.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: Referred the patient (Epstein) for evaluation, as noted in the subjective section of the medical record.

connections.description: The Warden referred inmate Epstein for a medical evaluation.

events.title: Initial Medical Encounter
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes an initial medical examination at MCC New York, documenting his vital signs, physical assessment, and medical history.

events.title: Chronic Care Physician Evaluation
events.description: Epstein is evaluated for chronic conditions including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, hypertension, constipation, low back pain, and neuralgia. A Medrol dose pack is prescribed for pain.

events.title: Hospital Transfer Prepared
events.description: A medical transfer form is generated, listing Epstein's active health problems and medications for potential transfer to a local hospital. The form notes 'R/O self Inflicted injuries' under health problems.

events.title: Medical Intake Cosign
events.description: Initial health services encounter for Jeffrey Epstein at MCC New York, including lab and radiology requests.

events.title: History & Physical Examination
events.description: Comprehensive medical examination of Jeffrey Epstein, documenting vital signs, medical history, social history, and physical assessment.

events.title: Medication Change Request
events.description: Epstein requested a change from bisacodyl to docusate sodium for constipation, which was approved and prescribed.

events.title: Dental Health Assessment
events.description: Dental health history screen and A&O exam performed, noting conditions like gingival recession and crowding.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injury
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit 205 - Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He had circular erythema (redness) on his neck and was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Refuses Eye Doctor Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed a Bureau of Prisons form refusing the recommended treatment for an eye doctor evaluation.

events.title: Epstein Implicates Cellmate
events.description: During a medical follow-up, Epstein stated, 'I think my room mate had to do with what happened to me,' in reference to the neck injury, but refused to elaborate further.

events.title: Epstein Reports Neuropathy Symptoms
events.description: Epstein reported waking up with a loss of control and 'pins and needles' in his right arm, which was evaluated by medical staff.

events.title: Epstein refuses chest X-ray
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs a medical treatment refusal form, declining a recommended routine chest X-ray.

events.title: Epstein refuses eye doctor evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs multiple medical treatment refusal forms, declining a recommended ophthalmologic evaluation.

events.title: Chronic care evaluation
events.description: Epstein is evaluated in the chronic care clinic. He reports being without his medications for a week, numbness in his right arm, sleep apnea, and other health issues. His CPAP machine is noted to have arrived.

events.title: Cardiac arrest and resuscitation attempt
events.description: A body alarm is activated for a medical emergency. Epstein is found unresponsive on the floor of his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He is cold, with circumferential bruising around the neck and posterior mottling. CPR is performed, he is intubated, and medications are administered. He is transported to a local ER with CPR in progress.

events.title: Epstein's Medical Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes a medical evaluation at the Bureau of Prisons Health Services. He reports being without his medications for about a week, experiencing right arm numbness 3 days prior, and not sleeping for 3 weeks due to lack of his CPAP machine.

locations: NEW YORK MCC (Metropolitan Correctional Center), 150 PARK ROW, NEW YORK, New York 10007
NYM (Facility abbreviation, likely MCC New York)
Mount Sinai Hospital (mentioned as past hospitalization location)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's detailed medical records from July-August 2019 show he had multiple chronic health issues: hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea (using a CPAP machine), hypertension, constipation, low back pain, neuralgia, prediabetes, and an elevated BMI.
A health problem listed on the transfer document dated August 10, 2019, includes 'R/O self Inflicted injuries' (Rule Out self-inflicted injuries), indicating this was a clinical consideration.
Epstein refused parts of his physical exam on July 9, 2019, specifically the rectal and male genitalia examinations.

The records document a stable but monitored health status with regular vital sign checks, blood glucose tests, and medication management (including insulin, Vascepa, and laxatives) during his incarceration.
The documents were generated by the Bureau of Prisons Health Services and include sensitive medical information marked 'SENSITIVE BUT UNCLASSIFIED'.

Jeffrey Epstein's medical records from July-August 2019 show he was prescribed medications for constipation (docusate sodium, bisacodyl, milk of magnesia), hypertriglyceridemia (Omega-3/Vascepa), and was issued a CPAP machine for sleep apnea.
Epstein's medical history included chlamydia in 2015 (treated), chicken pox in childhood, and he reported 10+ female sexual partners in the last 5 years with 'sometimes' condom use.
Lab results from July 9, 2019, showed significantly elevated triglycerides (413 mg/dL, normal 10-150) and cholesterol (216 mg/dL), with a low HDL level.
The records document multiple failed attempts to escort Epstein to a dental screening appointment in July 2019.
Epstein's medical duty status restricted him to a lower bunk, single cell, and he was not cleared for food service duties.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a rope around his neck, resulting in erythema (redness) and abrasions; he was placed on suicide watch.
Epstein implicated his cellmate in the neck injury incident on July 24, 2019, stating 'I think my room mate had to do with what happened to me,' but refused to provide details.
Epstein refused a recommended eye doctor evaluation on July 24, 2019, signing an official BOP treatment refusal form.
The medical records document ongoing health issues for Epstein including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, back pain, and neuropathy symptoms reported in late July.
All medical encounters took place at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, where Epstein was incarcerated.
Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, on the morning of August 10, 2019.
The clinical encounter report notes upon arrival he was "cold, with circumferential bruising around the neck and posterior mottling" and had "pupils fixed and dilated."
Epstein had refused several recommended medical treatments in July 2019, including a routine chest X-ray and an eye doctor evaluation.
In a July 30, 2019 evaluation, Epstein reported he had been without his medications for about a week and had experienced numbness in his right arm.
The document provides a detailed, minute-by-minute timeline of the resuscitation efforts performed on Epstein on August 10, 2019.
Jeffrey Epstein reported to medical staff on July 30, 2019, that he had been without his medications for about one week.
Epstein reported experiencing numbness in his right arm for 2-3 minutes, an event that occurred 3 days prior to the evaluation.
Epstein stated he had not slept for 3 weeks because he did not have access to his CPAP machine, which staff indicated would be returned to him that night.
The medical record lists multiple diagnoses for Epstein including constipation, prediabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, low back pain, neuralgia, and sleep apnea.
New medical orders were placed including medications for constipation and prediabetes, lab tests, and a cervical spine X-ray scheduled for August 29, 2019.
